div.head:
Embleme 25. Of the Secrets of Nature.
The Dragon dyes not, except hee be killdkilled by his brother and Sister,
which are Sol and Luna.

lg.l: To kill the dragon will much art require,
Soe sure as never after to respire:
Brother and Sister joyntlyjointly must invade
His life, 'causebecause nothing els can him degrade;
Luna his sister is, who Orion Slew,

div.head: Discourse 25.
div.ab:
In acquiring the golden fleece the Dragon was first of all to be killed, because-
the labour being attempted by many men, they were overcome by the Dragon-
and destroyd with deadly poyson: the reason was, because they were not sufficiently
armed against the dragons poyson, nor instructed, by what entrigneentrain hee-
might be slayneslain: but Jason (the Physician) neglected noe manner of reme
dyesremedies, whereof hee received severall from Medea (the advice of the mind) and-
amongst those the images of Sol and Luna, which using hee successefullysuccessfully ob
taindobtained the victory with the reward, that is, the Golden Fleece. The Dragon there
fore was slayne by Sol and Luna, or the images of them, which the Philosophers
doe in many places inculcate: for an Author of the Rosary amongst others hath it
thus: Hermes; The Dragon dyes not, except hee be killd by his brother and Sister,
not by one alone but by both together, to witt, by Sol and Luna. The Philoso
phers Mercury never dyes, except hee be killd by his Sister, that is, hee must be
congealdcongealed by Luna or Sol. Note, that the Dragon is Argent vive extracted from bo
dyes, having in it body, Soule, and Spirit, whereupon hee sayth: The Dragon dyes-
not, except by his brother and Sister, that is, Sol and Luna, that is, Sulphur ex
tracted, containing in it the nature of moistnessemoistness and coldnesse according to Luna,
by those the dragon dyes, that is, Argent vive extracted from the same bodyes at-
first, which is the Philosophers Aqua permanens, which is made after putre
faction, and after separation of the Elements, and that water is by another-
name called Aqua fætidafetida: these are his words: with whome all the rest doe-
agree, soeso that there is noe need to alleadgealleged the authority of every one: the
Epyreans worshippedworshiped the Dragon in the temple of Apollo in comemorationcommemoration of-
Python being slayne: WarreWar and hatred is genuine to the dragon with the Ele
phant, whose eyes and throat hee strikes at, till the Elephant falling on the-
ground kills the dragon with himselfe by the weight of his body, by which means
dragons blood is imported into our countryescountries: The Dragon hath eyes of the va
luation of gemmsgems: his sight is very acute and clear, and therefore hee is much
used for the keeping of treasures, as the apples of the Hesperides, and the gol
den fleece at Colchos aforesaydaforesaid: The Ancients ascribedascribed a dragon to ÆsculapiusAsculapius
as a HieroglyphickeHieroglypics: But the Chymists doe appropriate dragons to their opera
tions, not indeed really, but allegorically: for a dragon, whether hee be fixdfixed-
or volatile, allwayes denotes Mercury: for this reason Mercury is to be seen with
two serpents twisted about his wand (the Dragon being a great Serpent) and Sa
turne with one, which devouresdevours his tayletail, as allso Janus: A Serpent is conse
crated to ÆsculapiusAsculapius the Sonne of Apollo, the inventerinventor of medicine (Philo
sophicall medicine) in which forme hee is reported to be brought from Epi
daurus to Rome, and there allwayes worshippedworshiped for the cessation of the-
pestilence caused by him, as was supposed: But the Philosophers dragon is
allwayes most vigilant and lively, nor easily to be wounded, both by rea
son of the thicknesse of his skinne, and the sharpnessesharpness of his teeth-
and poyson, wherewith hee is armed: For though comon dragons are sayd
to be voyd of poyson, yet this is not without it, venting it upon any one

in his way, if hee be not warily managed: Hee can therefore be rarely over
come by force, except the craft of his consanguine relations be allso added: For
the Poet sayd truely, It is a safe and usuall way to deceive by the name-
of a freind, yet though it be a safe and usuall way, it is a crime, which is soeso

brother and Sister together, that is, by Sol and Luna: from whence it appears
that the dragon is allso one of the PlanettsPlanets, to witt, Mercury extracted from
bodyes, as hath been allready manifested by the Rosary: Some of the Græ

rightly handled, leaves his fiercenessefierceness, and becomes a freind to man, though
hee be malicious, if otherwise. Xanthus the historian is a wittnessewitness with-
Pliny, that the young of a dragon being killdkilled was restored by the parent
to life with the herbe, which hee calls Balin: which notwithstanding I as
cribe to a Philosophicall allegory, rather than true history, for life is re

But some man may enquire, where and how the dragon must be taken?-
The Philosophers answer by a verse most concisely,
Dant Rebis montes, draconis, terraq, fontes:
But you may see Tacitus of the way of taking him, with what care and
industry many men watchdwatched to take a mighty dragon observdobserved in Africa,
